div.head: Chapter I
div.p: In the spring of 1927, Clara Villard arrived in Trieste to study the archives of Sigismund Klein, a reclusive scholar who had spent his final years in Dubrovnik. Clara, then only twenty-three, had been sent by Professor L. Harding of Oxford, who believed that Klein’s lost manuscript on chronotopic memory1 might surface. She stayed at a boarding house run by Giulia Cantarini, a widowed pianist with a collection of rare maps of Istria. Each evening, Clara would walk the Riva degli Schiavoni2, comparing the fading shorelines with those marked on Giulia’s tattered charts.

Her research took an unexpected turn when she uncovered a bundle of letters in the Biblioteca Civica of Padua, written by Aurelio Fontana, a forgotten diplomat turned mystic. The letters referenced the so-called Doctrine of Residual Presence3, a term Clara had encountered only once before—in a footnote of an unpublished lecture by Klein himself. Torn between returning to Oxford and following Fontana’s trail to Palermo, Clara wrote to Harding for advice, enclosing transcriptions of the letters and her own speculative notes4. The answer, however, never came.

div.note: chronotopic memory A theoretical concept derived from literary theory—especially the work of Mikhail Bakhtin—referring to the fusion of time and space in narrative. In this context, it implies a structure of memory where places evoke specific temporal layers, often used to interpret texts with fragmented or layered timelines.

Riva degli Schiavoni Traditionally, the waterfront promenade in Venice named after Slavic merchants. In this passage, it may be metaphorically applied to Trieste to evoke its Adriatic cosmopolitanism, even though the name does not strictly belong there—highlighting Clara’s symbolic mapping.

Doctrine of Residual Presence A speculative philosophical idea attributed to fringe mystical thinkers of the early 20th century. It suggests that personal or historical identities leave enduring, perceivable traces in physical locations, documents, or even memories—though the doctrine lacks academic validation.

Clara’s speculative notes These were later catalogued among the Harding Papers at Oxford but were not published until 1953 in Posthumous Writings of the Viennese Circle. They reflect Clara’s early theories on intertextual mysticism, influenced by Klein and Fontana’s esoteric writings.
